attributes.comment:
After suffering through years of primary infertility, and after very careful
consideration, we began the process of International adoption in September 2005.
We understood the nature of the process involved some unpredictability timing
wise, due to interfacing with a foreign country, however, what has been completely
unexpected is the process and dramatic increase of fees incurred via the USCIS
in obtainaining a valid I-171H.

We have already paid the required fees for fingerprinting and I-600A form once,
and are now in the process of having to renew and RE-PAY for not only these
same items... but, also to update our homestudy (that is still valid in our state for
24 months), but is required by the USCIS to be updated prior to renewal of the I-
600A.

Being required to renew these expiring documents adds an excessive and
unnecessary financial burden on us and many other adoptive families who are
already stretched trying to meet the costs of International adoption. These fees
add approximately $2,000 additional dollars to the expected cost of well above
$20,000 in total.

We are supportive of our country and it's efforts to secure our borders and the
safety of it's citizens. However, I would request that the USCIS extend the
expiration time of the I-171H to 24 months for those pursuing International
adoption rather than contributing to the heavy costs incurred by families.

By extending the expiration timeframe for adoptive families, the additional
workload of the USCIS employees who are having to re-process paperwork for
thousands of adoptive families would be reduced, thereby reducing the need for
additional employees and the increased payroll costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this matter.

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
